description: The Certified Information Systems Auditor (CISA) designation is a globally recognized certification for IS audit control, assurance and security professionals. Being CISA-certified showcases your audit experience, skills and knowledge, and demonstrates you are capable to assess vulnerabilities, report on compliance and institute controls within the enterprise. One should have a minimum of 5 years of experience and be able to demonstrate proficiency and understanding across the 5 domains areas, which include auditing information systems, protection of information assets and others.
name: CISA
subtitle: Certified Information Systems Auditor

episodes.description: The Certified Information Systems Auditor (CISA) designation is a globally recognized certification for IS audit control, assurance and security professionals. Being CISA-certified showcases your audit experience, skills and knowledge, and demonstrates you are capable to assess vulnerabilities, report on compliance and institute controls within the enterprise. One should have a minimum of 5 years of experience and be able to demonstrate proficiency and understanding across the 5 domains areas, which include auditing information systems, protection of information assets and others.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Brian and Mike discuss best practices and tips for preparing for the CISA exam.
episodes.title: CISA Exam Preparation

topics.title: The Process of Auditing Information Systems

episodes.title: Governance and Management in IT Part 2
Governance and Management in IT Part 3
Governance and Management in IT Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian continue explaining some key terms and definitions in reference to systems acquisitions, development, and implementation. Here they run through many terms and concepts that deal with Project Management which includes Request for Proposal, Project Portfolio, and Program Evaluation and Review Techniques(PERT). They also cover IT Resources and the IT Portfolio.
episodes.title: Acquisition, Development and Implementation Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian describe what is involved with software acquisition. They also describe 2 software development models; the traditional Waterfall model which is slow to implement but highly reliable, and the Agile model which is fast to deploy, but can be more insecure. They also discuss the importance of Input controls as well as Quality Assurance(QA) and Quality Management(QM).
episodes.title: Acquisition, Development and Implementation Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian discuss the Human Resource element of systems acquisition, development, and implementation. They give you an overview of the many IT job roles like IT Operations Manager, System Architect, Change Control Manager, App developer, and Help Desk Support, and their importance.
episodes.title: Acquisition, Development and Implementation Part 5

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian explore the importance of change management. They begin by explaining what change management is as well as explaining change management boards or committees and how they operate. They also talk about how change requests create a proper documentation for an audit trail.
episodes.title: Acquisition, Development and Implementation Part 6

topics.title: Information Systems Acquisition, Development and Implementation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian: Talk about ITIL framework and how it help IT deliver IT services to end users be they sys admin, CIO, or other workers. using frameworks and change management information as metrics to manage risk.
episodes.title: IS Ops, Maintenance and Service Mgmt.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian discuss conducting reviews of IT systems. They start by going through the different types of storage like local storage (Physical Spinning Drives & SSD), attached storage (SAN & NAS), and removable storage(flash). They also discuss network devices (routers & switches). Finally they cover network redundancy and management devices like SEIMs, Firewalls, and DMZs.
episodes.title: IS Ops, Maintenance and Service Mgmt. Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian talk about evaluating IT operations for the purpose of discovering their effectiveness. Then they explain the process of End of Sale(EoS); what to do when a vendor stops selling a product you use, and End of Life(EoL); what to do when a vendor stops supporting a product you use. Of course they explain how this all is dealt with through change management.
episodes.title: IS Ops, Maintenance and Service Mgmt. Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian discuss how patches and updates are handled as well as the effectiveness thereof. They talk about upgrade and patching policies in production and test environments. They cover preventative measures like checking with vendors for compatibility issues, and creating an effective patch back-out plan.
episodes.title: IS Ops, Maintenance and Service Mgmt. Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian explore the world of database management. They look at proper database access and storage techniques, as well as security measures like obfuscation and encryption. Also covered are design and optimization, database users (data owner, custodian, and admin), and the Data Lifecycle.
episodes.title: IS Ops, Maintenance and Service Mgmt. Part 5

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian talk about incident management which is basically how to properly handle an incident. They explain how you can use your change management process as incident prevention. They look at how incidents should be reported. Also, they discuss Disaster Recovery and Business Continuity Drills and "What if?" scenarios.
episodes.title: IS Ops, Maintenance and Service Mgmt. Part 6

topics.title: Information Systems Operations, Maintenance and Service Management

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian begin their discussion of protecting IS assets. They begin with looking at the concept of the CIA triad (Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability). They also go over privacy laws and regulations in the US and other countries. Finally, they talk about physical security measures which include things like wet/dry pipe fire suppression, HVAC, Fences, and locks with alerting systems for all.
episodes.title: Protecting Information Assets

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian continue their discussion of protecting IS assets. Here they turn their focus towards logical access controls and biometric devices (hand/fingerprint, facial recognition, iris/retina) and voice recognition. They discuss the Type-1 and Type-2 errors associated with those devices. Finally, they describe external attacks from Malware (viruses, worms, trojans) to DOS/DDOS, Phishing, Ransomware, Drive-By, and Advanced Persistent Threat(APT).
episodes.title: Protecting Information Assets Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian take a look at testing software and hardware for security weaknesses. They begin by discussing enumeration and host discovery. Then they move on to Vulnerability Assessment(VA) and Penetration Testing as well as the differences between them. Finally they explore the 3 types of Pen tests which include Black-box, Grey-box, and White-box. Also covered are Credentialed vs. Non-Credentialed scans.
episodes.title: Protecting Information Assets Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian take time to introduce you to the Open Systems Interconnect(OSI) 7-layer networking model. The OSI model has been a long used system for standardizing how computer networks should operate which leads to greater interoperability between systems. Here they break down each of the 7 layers and their functions as well as explaining the encapsulation/decapsulation process.
episodes.title: Protecting Information Assets Part 4

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian explore some common ports and services that you may encounter in any given networked system. Here they run down a list of common port numbers and their associated services, which includes, but is not limited to, File Transfer Protocol(FTP: Ports 20/21), Secure Shell(SSH: Port 22), and Transport Layer Security(TLS/SSL: Port 443).
episodes.title: Protecting Information Assets Part 5

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Brian explain how Public Key Infrastructure(PKI) systems work. PKI can be mystifying to many, so here it is broken down step-by-step to show you each of the components and how the Public and Private Keys are used to encrypt/decrypt data and insure data integrity through Digital Signatures.
episodes.title: Protecting Information Assets Part 6
